Turn a programming project into a text-network

get_text_network_from_project.Rmd

Assuming you have folder path(s) and/or public github repo(s) from a programming project, codexplor::get_text_network_from_project will compute a Citations Network of the programming project(s) :

  • the network is directed,
  • indegrees of a node is ‚Äòhow many functions of the project uses this precise func‚Äô.
  • Outdegree of a node is ‚Äúhow many functions of the project are used by this precise function‚Äù.
  • ‚ü≤ auto-mentioning typically reveal ‚Äòrecursivity‚Äô, once a func‚Äô call itself more than one times (1st mention is usually for define the func‚Äô name)

Assuming the user have indicated a list of folders paths and/or github repo(s), codexplor::get_text_network_from_project() will :

‚è© Read the files, trying to extract a 1st pattern (e.g., defaults parameters will extract R functions names, when a func‚Äô is defined within a file). ‚è© Search for these patterns (functions names by default) in the initial content, in order to constitute a Citations Network. üéÅ Return the edgelist of the network of documents (i.e.¬†files path with the 2nd match => files path with the 1st match [where the function is defined])

For example, giving a bunch of .R codes files path and/or url :

net <- get_text_network_from_project(repos =  c("tidyverse/stringr", "clement-lvd/codexplor"), regex_to_exclude_files_path = "test-")
# these func' are tunned for detecting R func' by default
get_networkd3_from_igraph(codexplor::get_igraph_from_df(net) )

For ex. we see that codexplor rely on stringr functions. The opposite is not true.

There is sometimes a false positive nodes that need to be excluded from the network. Typical ‚Äúfalse positive‚Äù matches are the lines where you use the name of another function in a message, e.g.¬†message("my_func() is deprecated. You should use this_function() instead). get_text_network_from_files offer several parameters for deal with your style of programming.
